posts.content:
Brewing…

The first blog is brewing. It will be ready to be served in a couple of minutes. Thanks for your patience.

content_blocks.image_alt: Rui Hu in Phoenix South Mountain

content_blocks.title: About me
content_blocks.description: This page is focused on my career life.

content_blocks.content_html:
I am lucky to experience or have experienced different roles in my life. The following are the most typical ones.

Started as an 

Educator

When it comes to making a difference in the world, educators have been on top of the list. Two years ago, I realized my dream to be an educator and successfully landed a part-time teaching job at Northern Arizona University (NAU) and later a full-time position at Academy of Math and Science (AMS), a K-8 school in Phoenix, Arizona, United States. 

As an educator, it has always been my passion and determination to enlighten students and help them capture the “aha” moments. They also reminded me of capturing my sparkles and pushing my limits higher. These years, I have gradually solidified my interests and passion in  linguistics & computer science, especially data science and natural language processing (NLP). I have reinforced my aspiration to be a computational linguist and data scientist.

with the stepping stone of being a

Language Enthusiast & Translator

I found myself passionate in languages at a young age, when I quickly picked up dialects that my family members were speaking - Xiang Chinese (also with different variations: Urban Changsha, Ningxiang, and Xiangtan) and Cantonese. In middle school, I started to expose myself to a second foreign language (French) and I started to learn it systematically when I was in college. I am learning Spanish and Finnish at the moment. By obtaining my first master's degree in Translation at the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), I also honed my skills in translation and interpretation. I am happy to have worked for National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and PAC-12 with Arizona State University (ASU), and for Institue Français (French Institute) with Embassy of France in China, as well as other organizations when I was working part-time as a translator and interpreter.

My goal is to be a

Linguist & Data Scientist

My never-ending interests in computers date back to my childhood, when my parents opened a new Pentium III computer right from the box. At the age of 6, excited and surprised, I started my journey to fiddle around with my new toy. I started coding in Python 2.x when I was in high school. At Hunan University (HNU) in China, I was working part-time as a Full Stack Developer in 1000 Internet and Culture Studio (link is in Chinese), a student-operated studio. In Spring 2021 at NAU, I was fortunate to take Programming for Text Analysis with Dr. Egbert, and it further thrusted my passion for integrating computer science and linguistics. Presently, as a Foreign Language Teacher in Phoenix, I always strive to make a tight integration of my current job and future envisions. Elected as the Director of the AMS South Mountain Robotics and Programming Club, I am actively playing a leading role in the Club started in January 2022. 

Propelled by ambition and desire to become a well-developed linguist and data scientist, I also keep sharpening my coding and data analysis skills (Python & R) on DataCamp and Udemy. Meanwhile, I have also taught myself algorithms and statistical methods regarding NLP and computational linguistics. I am also glad I have been, once again, an active GitHub stargazer and user since the end of 2021. 

Questions?

For more information, please check out my CV. If you have any questions about me or my research/work, please feel free to connect with me, by clicking any button below to connect with me on social media.

content_blocks.title: Blog
content_blocks.description: This serves as a blog that logs various topics that I am interested in sharing.

content_blocks.title: Hey there, I am Rui Hu
content_blocks.description_html:
Also known as Sherman, Rui (pronounced as ROO-ee in English), or 胡睿 (Hú Ruì in Chinese).

 

I aspire to be an Applied and Computational Linguist and Data Scientist.

 

Currently, I work as a K-8 educator in South Phoenix, Arizona, USA. In my spare time, I enjoy sharpening my programming and data analysis skills. I am also fond of traveling and taking photos. Swimming is my favorite sport, though I am probably in the snack aisle.
content_blocks.image_alt: Rui Hu's picture in Kallo Finland

content_blocks.content_html:
Research Interests

My main research interests are in applying both linguistic and computational approaches to investigate the properties (such as meaning) of natural languages in use through corpora. Topics of interests include discourse and sentiment analysis, natural language processing/understanding, phonetics, syntax-semantics interface, as well as language and speech.

Projects

The following is a list of selected and categorized projects that I have completed. The projects can also be found on my GitHub page. If you are interested in my research projects, you are welcome to check the Research Page.

Natural Language Processing (NLP)

  • A prototype poetry generator based on Markov model (source code)
  • A prototype text classifier based on Markov model (source code)
  • A prototype sentiment analyzer with logistic regression (source code)
  • A prototype recommender system using non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) and cosine similarity (source code)
  • Discovering topics (interpretable features) in Wikipedia articles with non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) (source code)
  • Clustering Wikipedia articles and titles based on a given TD-IDF array in CSR matrix format with k-means (source code)
  • Latent semantic analysis (LSA) visualization with singular value decomposition (SVD) (source code)

Machine Learning

Classification

  • Predicting credit card approvals (notebook)
  • Clustering fish species using k-means (source code)
  • Clustering grain seeds using k-means, hierarchical clustering, and t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) (source code)
  • Predicting handwritten digits: a multi-class classification with k-nearest neighbors (KNN) (source code)
  • Predicting party affiliation: a binary classification with k-nearest neighbors (KNN) (source code)
  • Predicting whether a given Pima Indian will have diabetes: a binary classification with k-nearest neighbors (KNN) (source code)
  • Pima Indian diabetes classification using logistic regression (source code)
  • Discovering variance of the PCA features in fish species (source code)
  • De-correlating grain seed data and dimension reduction with PCA (source code)

Regression

  • Life expectancy prediction with linear regression (source code)

Data Science

Data analysis and visualization

  • Analyzing TV data (notebook)
  • Investigating Netflix movies and guest stars in the office (notebook)
  • The Android app market on Google Play (notebook)

Other

  • An interactive web recorder (source code)
  • Just for fun: drawing fun patterns with Python (source code)

content_blocks.title: Research
content_blocks.description: Currently, this page only highlights the major research projects that I have completed. Other than the following projects, you can find some other projects in the Miscellaneous page.

content_blocks.content_html:
Building a Twitter Scraper & a Prototype Dictionary-based Sentiment Analyzer

  • Northern Arizona University, individual work, 2021
  • Course: Programming for Text Analysis
    • Created several Python programs and collected Tweets (N = 3,200) from Twitter and built a corpus of Tweets;  
    • Created a prototype dictionary-based sentiment analyzer and created a scoring system of the sentiment;
    • Compared the scoring by the prototype dictionary-based sentiment analyzer against the one by pre-trained machine learning sentiment analyzer;
    • Discussed the implications for sentiment dictionary building and applied linguistics research

Second Language (L2) English Speaker Analysis

  • Northern Arizona University, individual work, 2020
  • Course: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
    • Interviewed a non-native English speaker (N = 1) and collected the speech data by recording the interview with a semi-structured protocol;
    • Comprehensively analyzed the speech data at the levels of phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics/lexicon;
    • From the perspective of L1-L2 transfer, analyzed the features of the speaker's speech and summarized the features that were rooted in the speaker's first language (L1) and the ones that were independent of the speaker's L1;
    • Provided a summary of potential instructional priorities on improving the speaker's English speaking

Characteristics of a Reading Comprehension Assessment: Measures of Validity and Reliability

  • Northern Arizona University, collaborative work, 2020
  • Course: Assessment for Second Language Skills
    • Developed a test to measure native and non-native English speakers' reading comprehension in the context of academic English (N = 26);
    • Investigated the validity and reliability of the test;
    • Examined the test results by referring to descriptive statistics (mean, mode, midpoint, maximum, and minimum) and data distribution (standard deviation, skewness, and kurtosis of the curve);
    • Discussed whether there was a statistically significant difference between the test results of native speakers and those of non-native speakers

Native and Non-native Speakers' Perception of American English Dialects

  • Northern Arizona University, collaborative work, 2020
  • Course: Sociolinguistics
    • Discussed to what extent both native and non-native speakers perceive different dialects in the US regarding correctness and pleasantness (N = 54)
    • Performed independent t-tests of correctness and pleasantness scores to examine whether there was a statistically significant difference between native and non-native speakers' ratings in terms of correctness and pleasantness
    • Discussed the implications for language teaching and teacher training

Traveling is fun, isn't it?
